questions.question: What is Football EyeQ?
questions.answer: Football EyeQ is a cognitive training platform that helps coaches develop game intelligence in players. While traditional training focuses on technical skills in isolation, Football EyeQ bridges the gap between technical ability and cognitive awareness. The platform provides a curated library of 100+ research-backed drills, intelligent filtering to design progressive sessions, season planning tools, and smart LED cone integration. Think of it as your complete system for teaching players to see more, think faster, and decide better on the pitch.

questions.question: Why is cognitive training important in football?
questions.answer: Research shows that elite players scan the field 8x more than average players before receiving the ball, and make decisions in 0.5 seconds under match pressure. Players who scan more have 23% better pass accuracy. Traditional training often focuses on technical skills in predictable environments, but real matches require constant scanning, processing information about 21 moving players, and split-second decisions under pressure. Cognitive training systematically develops these mental skills alongside technical ability. By training players to see more, think faster, and decide better, you're giving them the game intelligence that separates good players from elite ones.

questions.question: How do I get started with Football EyeQ?
questions.answer: Getting started is simple! First, create a free account at the signup page - you'll get immediate access to the full drill catalogue, 1 session planner, and 10 favorites. Next, explore the drill catalogue using the filters (age group, difficulty, game moment) to find exercises that match your team's needs. Then, build your first session by adding 3-5 drills to your planner. Finally, use the session details to run training with your team. You can start with traditional cones (Plastic exercises) and upgrade to smart LED cones (EyeQ exercises) later if you'd like. Everything syncs to the cloud, so you can plan on your laptop and access it from your phone on the pitch.

questions.question: What's the difference between Free and Premium accounts?
questions.answer: Free accounts are perfect for getting started - you get full access to the drill catalogue with all filters, 1 session planner, up to 10 favorites, and community reviews. Premium accounts ($29/month) unlock the full 12-session season planner so you can plan your entire season progression, unlimited favorites to build a complete coaching library, session stats and analytics, and export functionality. The key difference is planning scope: Free lets you plan week-to-week, while Premium enables full seasonal progression from Basic to Elite difficulty over 12 weeks. Both accounts get the same quality drills and features - Premium just gives you more planning capacity.

questions.question: What's the difference between EyeQ and Plastic exercises?
questions.answer: Great question! This is a key distinction. **Plastic exercises** use traditional cones that you manually set up - these are the static cones every coach has. **EyeQ exercises** are designed for smart LED cones that light up in dynamic patterns controlled from the app. The cognitive difference is significant: with plastic cones, players can predict patterns and rely on memory. With smart LED cones, lights change unpredictably, forcing players to constantly scan, process visual information, and make real-time decisions - just like in a match. Both types teach the same cognitive principles, but EyeQ exercises add game-realistic unpredictability. The good news? You can use Football EyeQ with either equipment type!

questions.question: Do I need smart LED cones to use Football EyeQ?
questions.answer: No, absolutely not! Football EyeQ works with traditional cones too. The drill catalogue includes both **Plastic exercises** (for traditional cones) and **EyeQ exercises** (for smart LED cones). When browsing drills, you can filter by exercise type to see only what you can run with your current equipment. Many coaches start with Plastic exercises using their existing cones, then add smart LED cones later when they want to add dynamic visual cognitive load. Both types teach the same cognitive principles - smart cones just automate the unpredictability. You get full value from the platform regardless of equipment.

questions.question: How do the smart LED cones work?
questions.answer: Smart LED cones bring your session plans to life! Here's the flow: First, you design your session in the Football EyeQ app by adding EyeQ exercises to your planner. When you're ready to train, click 'Generate Code' in your session - this creates a unique numeric code tied to your drill patterns. Send that code to your smart LED cones, and they'll execute the light sequences automatically. During training, the cones provide color-coded visual cues that change dynamically and unpredictably, forcing players to scan constantly. This creates game-realistic cognitive load - players can't rely on patterns or memory; they must scan, process, and decide in real-time. The result? Training that develops scanning habits automatically.

questions.question: What's the difference between Individual and Club accounts?
questions.answer: Individual accounts are for coaches working independently - you pay for and manage your own subscription. Club accounts are for coaches who are part of an organization - your club admin pays for access and manages your account. As a **club coach**, you get all Premium features (12 sessions, unlimited favorites, stats) but your club admin controls your exercise type policy (EyeQ-only, Plastic-only, or Coach-choice) to ensure everyone uses the same equipment. Club admins get a dashboard to invite coaches, manage the roster, and set organization-wide policies. The benefit? If you're part of a club, your access is free to you and everyone uses a consistent methodology.

questions.question: How do I join my club's account?
questions.answer: If your club uses Football EyeQ, your club admin will send you an invitation email with a unique access code. Here's how to join: If you don't have an account yet, sign up at the signup page and check the box 'I have a club access code' - you'll be prompted to enter your code after creating your account. If you already have a free account, go to the Upgrade page and enter your invite code in the 'Join a Club' section. The code is valid for 7 days and is specific to your email address. Once redeemed, you'll automatically get full Premium features and be added to your club's roster. Your account becomes managed by your club admin, and you'll see exercises filtered by your club's equipment policy.

questions.question: What can club admins do?
questions.answer: As a club admin, you're the organization leader with full control over your coaching team. Your dashboard lets you: **Invite coaches** via email with unique access codes (7-day expiry), **manage your roster** by viewing all active coaches and pending invitations, **set exercise type policy** organization-wide (EyeQ-only, Plastic-only, or Coach-choice) to ensure equipment consistency, and **track team activity** to see who's using the platform. This ensures all your coaches use the same methodology, have access to the same tools, and train with compatible equipment. You also get all Premium features for your own coaching. Think of it as being both a coach and the team manager for Football EyeQ at your club.

questions.question: How do I invite coaches to my club?
questions.answer: From your Club Dashboard, go to the 'Invite New Coach' section. Enter the coach's email address and click 'Generate Invite'. Once a coach redeems the code, they're automatically added to your roster with full Premium access, and they'll see exercises filtered by your club's equipment policy.

questions.question: What is an exercise type policy and why set one?
questions.answer: An exercise type policy is an organization-wide setting that controls which drills your coaches can see, based on your club's equipment. There are three options: **EyeQ-only** (all coaches see only smart LED cone drills - for professional clubs with full hardware), **Plastic-only** (all coaches see only traditional cone drills - for grassroots clubs without smart hardware), and **Coach-choice** (coaches can toggle between both types - for hybrid clubs with mixed equipment). Setting a policy ensures consistency - no coach plans a drill they can't execute, everyone trains with the same equipment, and your methodology is aligned across all age groups and teams. You can change this policy anytime from your Club Dashboard.

questions.question: How do I find the right drills for my team?
questions.answer: The drill catalogue has a 6-dimensional filtering system designed to help you find exactly what you need. Start with **Age Group** (Foundation U7-U10, Youth Development U11-U14, Advanced U15-U18, or Senior) to match your players' developmental stage. Then filter by **Difficulty** (Basic, Intermediate, Advanced, Elite) based on current ability. Use **Decision Theme** (Pass or Dribble, Attack or Hold, Shoot or Pass) if you're targeting specific cognitive choices. **Game Moment** (Build-Up, Counter Attack, Defensive Shape, etc.) helps find drills that match your tactical system. **Player Involvement** (Individual, Pairs, Small Groups, Team Units) scales to your training group size. Finally, **Practice Format** (Rondo, Small-Sided Game, Shooting Pattern, etc.) adds variety. Each filter works together - set multiple filters to narrow down to perfect drills for today's session!

questions.question: What are session codes and how do I use them?
questions.answer: Session codes are the bridge between digital planning and on-field execution with smart LED cones! When you've built a session with EyeQ exercises, click the 'Generate Code' button in your planner. This creates a unique 6-character numeric code that maps your drills to specific cone light patterns. You can display this as a QR code or enter it manually into your LED cone controller. The cones then execute the programmed light sequences for your drills automatically. This means you design strategically at home, then execute seamlessly on the pitch - no manual cone reprogramming between drills. Note: Session codes only work with EyeQ exercises and smart LED cone hardware. For Plastic exercises with traditional cones, you'll use the drill diagrams for manual setup.

questions.question: What is the See-Think-Do methodology?
questions.answer: See-Think-Do is the three-pillar framework that underpins all Football EyeQ drills. **SEE** trains visual awareness - players learn to constantly scan the field, gathering information about teammates, opponents, space, and the ball before they receive it. **THINK** develops rapid decision-making - processing that visual information to identify the best option (pass or dribble, attack or hold, shoot or pass) in under 0.5 seconds. **DO** builds confident execution - turning smart decisions into effective actions under pressure. Traditional training often jumps straight to 'Do' with isolated technical practice. Football EyeQ integrates all three pillars in every drill, because in real matches, players must see, think, AND do simultaneously. This is how you build complete, intelligent footballers.

questions.question: What age should I start cognitive training?
questions.answer: You can start as early as U7! The drill catalogue is organized into four age groups: **Foundation Phase (U7-U10)** focuses on building basic scanning habits and awareness in fun, simple drills. **Youth Development Phase (U11-U14)** adds decision-making under mild pressure with more complex scenarios. **Game Training Phase (U15-U18)** introduces game-realistic cognitive complexity and tactical awareness. **Performance Phase (U19-Senior)** delivers elite-level cognitive demands. The key insight: cognitive habits formed at 8-12 years old become automatic by 16. If you wait until players are teenagers to start cognitive training, you're trying to change ingrained habits instead of building good ones from the start. That said, it's never too late - even senior players benefit from systematic cognitive development.

questions.question: How many drills can I add to one session?
questions.answer: Each session can hold up to 5 drills. This is by design - a typical training session runs 60-90 minutes, and 5 well-chosen drills gives you: a warm-up (10-15 min), 2-3 main drills (15-20 min each), and a cool-down or small-sided game (15-20 min). More than 5 drills creates rushing and superficial training; fewer than 5 limits variety. The system prevents you from adding a 6th drill to ensure quality over quantity. If you try to add too many, you'll see a message reminding you of the 5-drill limit. This constraint helps you plan focused, effective sessions rather than overwhelming players with too many concepts in one day.

questions.question: How do I build progression across a 12-week season?
questions.answer: Seasonal progression is built into the planner design! Start your season with Basic difficulty drills and simple decision themes. Weeks 1-3 might focus on fundamental scanning habits with Foundation or Youth Development age-appropriate exercises. Weeks 4-6 introduce Intermediate difficulty, adding game moments like Build-Up or Counter Attack. Weeks 7-9 move to Advanced drills with more complex decision themes (Pass or Dribble, Attack or Hold). Weeks 10-12 culminate in Elite difficulty with full game-realistic scenarios. The key is gradual progression - don't jump from Basic to Elite in one week. Layer complexity: start with individual exercises, progress to pairs, then small groups, then team units. Mix practice formats (Rondo â†’ Positional Play â†’ Small-Sided Games) for variety. The 6-dimensional filters help you map this progression systematically.

questions.answer: Yes, subscriptions are cancel-anytime with no long-term commitment. If you're on an Individual Premium plan, you can cancel from your account settings and your access continues until the end of your current billing period, then reverts to the free tier (1 session planner, 10 favorites). Your existing session plans and favorites are preserved within the free limits. For club subscriptions, the club admin manages cancellation - when a club subscription ends, all coaches revert to individual free accounts. The cancel-anytime policy removes risk from upgrading. If your coaching situation changes, you're not locked in. This flexibility reflects a coach-first approach where subscriptions are earned month-to-month through value, not contractual obligation.

questions.question: How do I generate a session code?
questions.answer: Once you've built a session with EyeQ exercises in your planner, open that session week and look for the 'Generate Code' button. Click it, and the system creates a unique 6-character numeric code that maps your drills to smart cone light patterns. You'll see the code displayed both as text and as a QR code that you can scan with your cone controller or phone. This code tells your LED cones which light sequences to run for each drill in your session. You can generate codes as many times as you need - each time you update your session drills, just regenerate the code. Note: Session codes only work with EyeQ exercises and smart LED cone hardware. Plastic exercises use manual cone setup instead.

questions.question: How do I rate a drill after using it?
questions.answer: After running a drill with your team, find it in the catalogue and click on the exercise card to view details. You'll see a rating section with 1-5 stars. Click the number of stars that reflects your experience: 1 star for 'not effective', 3 stars for 'decent', 5 stars for 'excellent for my team'. Your rating is submitted immediately and contributes to the drill's average community rating. This helps other coaches see which drills work well in real training environments. You can only rate each drill once, but your rating represents your overall assessment after using it. Consider: Did players engage? Was the cognitive load appropriate? Did it improve scanning and decision-making? Was setup time reasonable? Rate honestly to help the community!

questions.question: How can I see the most popular or highest-rated drills?
questions.answer: While browsing the drill catalogue, look at the star rating and review count displayed on each exercise card. The star rating shows the average community score (1-5 stars), and the number next to it shows how many coaches have rated it. Drills with higher ratings and more reviews are generally proven effective in real training. You can mentally sort by scanning for 4-5 star ratings with substantial review counts (10+ reviews is a good signal). Future versions may add explicit 'sort by rating' functionality, but for now, the visual star display on each card makes high-quality drills easy to spot. This community validation helps you prioritize which drills to try first when exploring new age groups or difficulty levels.

questions.question: How do I remove a drill from my session?
questions.answer: In your session planner, open the session week that contains the drill you want to remove. You'll see all drills currently in that session listed. Look for a remove icon (typically an 'X', trash can, or minus button) next to each drill. Click it to remove that drill from the session. The drill is only removed from your plan - it's not deleted from the catalogue, and you can re-add it anytime. Removing drills is useful when you're refining your session design, replacing drills with better-rated alternatives, or adjusting difficulty progression. There's no limit on how many times you can add and remove drills - experiment until your session feels right!

questions.question: Can I reorder drills within a session?
questions.answer: Drill order within a session may be fixed based on the order you added them, or you might have drag-and-drop reordering depending on the planner interface version. The typical training flow is: warm-up drill first, main drills in the middle, small-sided game or cool-down last. When building your session, add drills in the order you intend to run them. If you need to reorder, the current approach is to remove drills and re-add them in the desired sequence. Future updates may add explicit drag-and-drop reordering. Session order matters for pedagogical progression (simple â†’ complex within one session) and practical flow (high-intensity â†’ recovery periods). Plan your session structure before adding drills to minimize reordering needs.

questions.question: Can I use Football EyeQ offline?
questions.answer: Football EyeQ requires an internet connection for full functionality - browsing the catalogue, adding drills, and generating session codes all need cloud access. However, if you've loaded a session or drill details while online, your browser may cache that information temporarily. For reliable offline access, consider taking screenshots of your session drills or printing drill details before heading to the pitch. The platform is optimized for mobile data, so even with a basic cellular connection at your training ground, you can access your plans. Future versions may add offline mode with advanced caching, but currently, plan to have internet access when using the platform. This cloud-first design ensures you always see the latest drill ratings and your most recent session edits.

questions.question: What do the difficulty levels mean?
questions.answer: Difficulty levels indicate cognitive complexity and technical demands: **Basic** drills focus on fundamental scanning habits with simple decision-making in low-pressure environments - perfect for early development or introducing new concepts. **Intermediate** adds complexity with more game-realistic scenarios, moderate time pressure, and 2-3 decision options. **Advanced** drills feature game-realistic pressure, complex tactical scenarios, and require players to process multiple information sources simultaneously. **Elite** represents professional-level cognitive demands with high-speed decision-making, dense information environments, and consequences for poor choices. Difficulty isn't just about physical intensity - it's about cognitive load. A Basic drill can be physically demanding but cognitively simple. Progress difficulty gradually across your season: start Basic, end Elite.

questions.question: What are decision themes?
questions.answer: Decision themes are the specific cognitive choices that drills force players to make: **Pass or Dribble** trains recognizing when to release the ball vs. when to take players on. **Attack or Hold** develops knowing when to exploit space vs. when to maintain possession and wait. **Shoot or Pass** teaches final-third decision-making under pressure. These themes reflect the most common high-pressure decisions in matches. By filtering for a specific theme, you can target the cognitive skill your team struggles with. For example, if your players always dribble when they should pass, focus on 'Pass or Dribble' themed drills for 2-3 weeks. There's also a 'General/Unspecified' option for drills that develop overall awareness without forcing a specific binary choice.

questions.question: What are game moments?
questions.answer: Game moments are tactical scenarios that reflect when and where actions happen in real matches: **Build-Up** for progressing the ball from defense to attack. **Final Third Decision** for actions near the opponent's goal. **Defensive Shape** for organizing defensively. **Counter Attack** for rapid transition to exploit opponent imbalance. **Transition (Attack to Defend, Defend to Attack)** for the chaotic moments when possession changes. **Switch of Play** for changing the point of attack. Filtering by game moment helps you match drills to your team's tactical system and current match challenges. For example, if your team struggles with quick counters, focus on 'Counter Attack' drills. This creates game-realistic training that transfers directly to match situations.

questions.question: What does player involvement mean?
questions.answer: Player involvement indicates how many players participate in each drill, which affects setup, space requirements, and cognitive complexity: **Individual** drills are 1-player exercises for personal skill development (great for warm-ups or small training groups). **1v1 / 2v2** introduces direct opposition with minimal complexity (pairs work). **Small Group (3-4 players)** adds more decision options and scanning demands. **Team Unit (5+ players)** creates game-realistic density and information overload. Progression generally moves from Individual â†’ Pairs â†’ Small Groups â†’ Team Units across a season. Smaller groups = more touches and simpler decisions. Larger groups = fewer touches but more realistic game scenarios. Filter by player involvement based on your available squad size and training goals.

questions.question: What are practice formats?
questions.answer: Practice formats describe the structural type of drill, which affects training variety and player engagement: **Warm-Up / Ball Mastery** for low-intensity skill activation. **Fun Game / Physical** for fitness with enjoyment. **Finishing / Shooting Pattern** for goal-focused repetition. **Positional Possession Game** for maintaining shape under pressure. **Rondo / Tight Possession** for close-quarters ball circulation. **Directional Small-Sided Game** for mini-matches with tactical goals. Varying formats keeps training fresh - don't do rondos every day! Mix formats across your season: Monday = Rondo, Wednesday = Small-Sided Game, Friday = Shooting Pattern. Each format develops different aspects of game intelligence while teaching the same See-Think-Do principles. Use this filter to ensure variety in your session plans.

questions.question: What if I can't log in?
questions.answer: If you're having login trouble, try these steps: **Check your email and password** - ensure you're using the email you signed up with and the correct password (they're case-sensitive). **Reset your password** - use the 'Forgot Password' link on the login page to get a reset email. **Check your spam folder** - password reset emails sometimes land there. **Try a different browser** - browser extensions or cache issues can sometimes interfere. **Clear your browser cache** - old cached data can cause login problems. If none of these work, contact support with your email address and a description of the error message you're seeing. For club coaches, verify with your club admin that your invite was properly redeemed - sometimes login issues stem from incomplete club onboarding.

questions.question: What does 'Plastic' mean in exercise type?
questions.answer: 'Plastic' refers to traditional cone exercises - the standard static cones every coach already has. These are manually set up in specific patterns for drills, and they don't have any electronic components. The term 'Plastic' distinguishes these drills from 'EyeQ' drills that require smart LED cones. Plastic exercises teach the same cognitive principles (See-Think-Do, scanning, decision-making) but rely on coaching cues and manual pattern changes rather than automated light sequences. When you filter for Plastic exercises, you're seeing drills you can run with your existing equipment - no special purchase needed. This ensures Football EyeQ is accessible to all coaches regardless of equipment budget. Many successful coaches use only Plastic exercises and see excellent player development!

questions.question: Why is this called an 'EyeQ site' if it includes Plastic exercises?
questions.answer: Great observation! Football EyeQ is the platform brand - it represents the cognitive training methodology (See-Think-Do) and the complete ecosystem (Plan-Train-Enjoy). The 'EyeQ' name comes from developing players' 'Eye IQ' - their visual awareness and cognitive game intelligence. While the platform is designed to integrate with smart LED 'EyeQ' cones, it's built to serve ALL coaches, regardless of equipment. Plastic exercises are included specifically to help clubs get started with the methodology using traditional cones, with the option to add smart LED cones later as budget allows. Think of it this way: Football EyeQ is the coaching system; EyeQ cones are one tool within that system. The platform is 'EyeQ' because it develops Eye IQ in players - whether you use smart cones or traditional ones.

questions.question: Our club wants to start with Plastic and upgrade to EyeQ later - how does that work?
questions.answer: Perfect approach! Many clubs start exactly this way. As a club admin, set your exercise type policy to 'Plastic-only' when you register. All your coaches will see only traditional cone drills, and you can begin systematic cognitive training immediately with your existing equipment. Your coaches build session plans, develop the methodology, and see player improvement with Plastic exercises. When your club is ready to invest in smart LED cones (whether that's in 3 months or 3 years), simply change your exercise type policy to 'EyeQ-only' or 'Coach-choice' from your dashboard. Instantly, all your coaches gain access to smart cone drills. Their existing session plans remain, and they can now add EyeQ exercises or convert Plastic sessions to EyeQ versions. This staged approach lets you prove value with low upfront cost, then enhance with hardware when it makes sense financially.
